New leadership was mandated after the 1999 earthquake disaster.  At that time the government's response was deemed ineffectual and pathetic.  Now this new leadership is dropping the ball badly on this earthquake response even though far fewer lives are at stake.  When this response is evaluated a simple question will be asked.  Did Turkey's government do everything in its power to save and protect the lives of all its citizens?  Refusing all offers of outside assistance will not be viewed favorably.

In the half century since its 1956 independence from France, Tunisia has been practically a one-party state until Tunisians kicked out President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali in January after a monthlong popular uprising. Nine months of unrest, further demonstrations and political wrangling in the country of 10 million preceded Sunday's vote, which saw a huge turnout.
The constituent assembly elected will have an incredibly important role in building Tunisia's new democracy. It will not only appoint a new interim government but write the constitution that will determine how the country will function. If Ennanda party does not forcibly introduce Sharia (Islamic law)in the constituent assembly women can enjoy freedom.

"A horse, to me, is a livestock animal like a cow, sheep or a goat,” said Orbie Bonnett, a Nebraska rancher who stopped selling horses after prices plummeted. “A lot of folks nowadays look at a horse like a pet, like a dog or a cat. When you have a lot of money folk looking at this that way, well, there goes your slaughterhouses, there goes your market and there goes your horse folk — they just can’t make it anymore.” "

What a load of Horse Manure. The viewing of horses as companion animals is a normal expression of love for animals that fulfill a emotional need in their owners. With the passage of a comprehensive anti-slaughter bill the easy button would be removed and breeders would have no other choice but to breed quality over quantity. Lower supply, higher prices, fewer neglect issues....Not hard to comprehend. The same segment of the horse industry that insists they are livestock IE: We should be able to slaughter them for food if we want to, depends on the larger share of the market (horse owners that view them as companions) to buy what they produce. It is no more complicated than too many middle to lower end horses flooding the market. Supply and demand works the same in this industry as it does in any other. If we (the majority of horse owners) did not view them as pets, spending millions of dollars yearly on all the products out there for them, there would be very little demand for horses. Most people do not use them for work. They own them because they WANT to. Breeders can't have their cake and eat it too. Livestock animals vs companion animals? A lot of business men/women would cringe at the thought of us viewing them as livestock. No more expensive tack, toys, clothing, shampoos etc etc. I don't see all those products available for cows, sheep, pigs and chickens, but then they are livestock that are bred, born, raised and slaughtered just for our food. Conscientious breeders will stay in demand forever and those are the horse folk that we need.
Stop "loving" creatures and plants to death humans.  We are watching you.

Perhaps Mr. Holden could have looked at this film differently. It seemed quite obvious from the start that it was more of a fable or allegory and what meant to be seen as such. It never seemed to invoke a reality, (the sequencing and flashbacks saw to that), in a real gritty cinematic sense. But rather more in the vein of Terrance Malik picture, a visual tone poem. Regardless of the way this story is told, the production of this film is a stand out. Especially the photography which is a constant series of exquisitely composed and light  cinematic images. For that alone this film is worth watching and enjoying. The acting is good enough, the musical score and screenplay fade into the distance of this virtuoso performance of cinematic photography.

We adopted 3 children from Haiti and it was very traumatic for the older 2 and still is, but not as much for the youngest who spent more time with her birth family rather than in an orphanage. We know the birth families since we found someone to locate them and discovered what we had been told had been true. Our children were wanted by their parents but they could not take care of them. We keep contact with the birth families and when they are older, we will help our children visit their country and extended family if they desire to do so.
Being ripped away from your culture and being separated from your birth family is traumatic, and an enormous loss that many adoptees may only really experience when they are older and understand more. We can only try to lessen it by making sure that our children always have opportunities to know people from their culture.
I cannot relate to adoptive parents who try to minimize this loss or do not see the need to help their children stay connected to their culture. They are my children but they had another life, another set of parents and a heritage which we value.

You're missing something fundamental about what Lifton described. Separating a child from their mother is a trauma. Lifton talked about "premature ego development" which really relates more to Mahler's observations about separation/individuation than narratives. Narrative was more important to Lifton in the time that she grew up where it was taboo to want to know where you came from. But the trauma is not the gap in narrative, it's the impact of separation. Infants go through a phase where they spend many months coming out of symbiosis with their mother and gradually begin to have a separate sense of self. When a child is separated from their mother, that happens in one traumatic impact. How well they recover from it depends on circumstances and the capacity for both adoptive parents and child to bond to each other. That process is automatically handicapped from the lack of biological matching, mother's hormones, et al. But it leaves an imprint regardless of all of that.

Some of the things you mention that happen to non-adoptees are also traumas. IMO, better to recognize the traumas that befall us all rather than sweep under the rug the fundamental fact that the circumstances that cause adoption are traumatic to the child, and usually to the birthmother as well.

I long for a world where adoption and all other reproductive support and alternative methods for having a child are all made non-profit and completely transparent. Where every person can at least know as an adult where s/he came from. If the profit motive was removed from all of this, we'd have far fewer ethical/philosophical questions to grapple with.

For the last 20 years I've worked with educational projects in Guatemala. In the last decade, this work has frequently involved working with orphans, some of whom have lived/live with extended families, others who have found their way into some kind of orphanage (usually sponsored by one or another US Church, which can present other “cultural” problems). Also during this time, adoptions by US couples became a major scandal, resulting in the passage and implementation of draconian new Guatemalan laws concerning adoptions.

Early in the 2000’s, I shared several flights back to the US with 12 to 20 beaming US couples clutching just-past newborn (and too often screaming in unison) Guatemalan babies. At one level it was touching to see so many enthralled parents. At another level, there was something about this mass migration of innocents that I found unsettling, some hint of “cultural imperialism” that somehow offended me.

There is absolutely no question that new laws were needed in order to deal with corrupt Guatemalan agencies. I don't have any idea how well the laws have curbed unethical and illegal baby merchants in recent years. I do know from personal experience, however, that some of these new laws have posed serious obstacles to the well-being of many children by denying them the opportunity to be adopted by US couples.

Laws/enforcement changes fast in Guatemala, but as of last year orphans were routinely denied permanent residence in good homes, placed in the homes of relatives who don’t want or couldn’t care for them, or institutionalized in unwholesome circumstances because adoption to US couples became too difficult.

I’m still uncomfortable with wholesale adoption of developing world babies by developed world couples. What happened following enactment of Guatemala’s laws, however, pointed out clearly to me that many children who live in poor countries have a lot more to lose from “enabling violations” than by tight restrictions on adoption.

I, like some other posters here have stated, am troubled by the focus of so many middle/upper middle class families (especially white) on foreign adoptions. I have become even more troubled by the growing evidence that in many cases, including in China (the favored spot to adopt for many Americans), the children "voluntarily" given up for adoption were not actually given freely. This is extremely disturbing, and is something that many American adoptive parents choose to ignore. Like other posters, I wonder, why don't Americans want to adopt other American children? Yes, in many cases, they would not be white, but would be of African American descent. But why are Asian and Hispanic babies (from Paraguay, Guatemala) more desirable to American whites than American blacks?

The problem with "trauma" is that anything can be called a "trauma" (Consider the ubiquity or the "post-traumatic stress" syndrome).

At the same time, I have a friend who adopted a child born of a rape by a family friend. The famiy did not believe in abortion, and the teen carried the child to term and gave the infant up to an agency for adoption. I think this was a "trauma" for all involved, but the child was adopted into a loving family who accepts her as she is. Is this so bad? Why are so many comments here turning vicious against parents who adopt?

My daughter was adopted from an orphanage in southern Russia. Thinking about trauma of adaoption, when and to whom, I have to carefully weigh that thought. I have the documents, in Russian, that describe her birth and abandonment in the hospital by her mother a few days after she was born.

If she had not been adopted, she would have grown up in an orpanage without opportunity for a family to bond with or to nurture her. No, she doesn't speak Russian or have that much interest in Russia .Chances are that if she had grown up in the orphanage she would have headed for being a misfit in her own society.

Right now as a high school senior she is getting her EMT license and hopes to become a doctor in the future.

While the adoption of my daughter might have been traumatic in some ways, and I really believe it might be traumatic in many instances depending on the complex factors surrounding the adoptions themselves, including the family situations and the parents, it isn't always the case.
